title: Pension accessing fifties boost health short term study finds
story: Share this article Research of more than 7,000 people found that 41 per cent of the 55-year-olds studied withdrew the equivalent of £13,567 on average from their pension savings accounts.Participants were then asked to self-report their health on a scale of one to five – with one being 'poor', and five being 'excellent'.The study, published in the journal Economic Policy, calculated that for each £5,717 withdrawn health improved by 0.9 points.While the researchers from Korea University were unable to say exactly how this is boosting health, they suggested it may be a psychological effect of getting access to some of one's hard-earned savings.

title: Dozy long eared owl chick lets huge yawn perches tree branch sunrise
story: Share this article The owl chick is likely no more than a few days old, but has already developed some adult plumage. Wayne, 53, was 'over the moon' with the owl sighting as adult long-eared owls are considered to be 'the most elusive owls in the country', he said. The building company site manager, from Bedlington, Northumb, said: 'It was just fantastic, to get a photo like that. It's like gold dust.'You very rarely see an adult long-eared owl, because they're so shy and elusive.'But this one was just a youngster - probably about three or four days old - and was totally unfazed by me being there.'I kept creeping closer and closer to it, and moving round to capture it from different angles.'Then it yawned, and I couldn't help but laugh to myself  I had a friend with me who joked that the owl seemed bored of being photographed.'Wayne added that he went back to the nature reserve on Tuesday morning to try and get another glimpse of the owl chick and its family  but, whilst he could hear them, he did not see them again.

title: Former Newsround boss announced replacement Radio 4s Today programme
story: Share this article 'She could not bear working through years of job losses so decided to give up hers first,' one said.And in an email to staff, seen by The Guardian, she said: 'I have decided that September is a good time to move on and pass this job to someone else. I loved Radio 4 as a listener, I loved it even more as a member of the team. 'But I come from a different world and I was never going to be a lifer. I am so proud of what we have achieved, championing intelligent broadcasting and political independence, under constant pressure.'I have witnessed not only extraordinary professionalism and quick-witted determination here but also a heart-warming consideration towards one another. 'The Today programme is a beacon of news journalism. It was, is, will always be, the most precious programme at the BBC.'During her tenure, Ms Sands has faced criticism over the direction the programme has taken amid falling listener numbers. She came under fire for allegedly making the programme 'too soft'. But later hit back and said people had been polarised by Brexit and found it 'intolerable' to hear views they disagreed with.After news of her departure was revealed, BBC director of news Fran Unsworth said: 'Sarah has brought new ideas and fresh thinking to the Today programme over the past three years.'Under her editorship she has broadened the programme's agenda, putting a renewed focus on science and arts, and left the nation scratching their heads with the puzzle for Today.'She has commissioned a series of formidable guest editors from Greta Thunberg to the Duke of Sussex. We thank her for all her hard work and wish her well for the future after she leaves the programme this summer.'

title: Covid mini budget live Latest analysis reaction
story: Last month, there were rumours of a scrappage scheme - but it appears that the scrappage scheme was scrapped before it got started.Mike Hawes, Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders chief executive, tells deputy motoring editor Rob Rull: 'It&rsquos bitterly disappointing the Chancellor has stopped short of supporting the restart of one of the UK&rsquos most important employers and a driver of growth.'The automotive sector has been particularly hard hit, with thousands of job losses already announced and many more at risk.'Of Europe's five biggest economies, Britain now stands alone in failing to provide any dedicated support for its automotive industry, a situation that will only deter future investment.'We urgently need government to expand its strategy and introduce sector-specific measures for UK auto to support cash flow such business rate holidays, tax cuts, and policies that provide broader support for consumer confidence and boost the big ticket spending that drives manufacturing.'Until critical industries such as automotive recover, the UK economic recovery will be stuck in low gear.'Graduates and jobseekers reactGraduates and jobseekers have welcomed the Government's &pound2billion 'Kickstart' scheme to create more jobs for young people.Reporter Grace Gausden speaks to five under-25s for their reaction to the scheme, some of whom are graduating this summer.Pub industry not happy eitherGreg Mulholland, campaign director for the Campaign for Pubs, said that what was needed from the Chancellor was a 5 per cent cut in VAT across in the board in the hospitality sector, not just specific sections of it, writes Jane Denton.Mr Mulholland said: 'Instead Rishi Sunak has decided to help only pubs that do food and overnight accommodation and has done nothing at all to help thousands of beloved community locals up and down the country, which is unfair.'The Government appears to be turning its back on the traditional community local, many can't trade profitably due to restrictions and yet are being offered no support.'We urge the Chancellor to think again, or we will see the closures of many valued pubs, including in his own constituency.&nbspWe welcome the help for pubs serve food and offer bed and breakfast, but are dismayed at the lack of any support for all other pubs and we will now be lobbying the Government to help all pubs through the ongoing crisis, not just some of them.'He added: 'Today is great news for the likes of Wetherspoons but awful for independent pubs.'Tom Stainer, CAMRA's chief executive, said he was also concerned that pubs had been 'left behind' in the Chancellor's statement.Mr Stainer added: 'It is disappointing to see no direct support for independent brewers and producers, who will not benefit from a VAT cut that specifically excludes beer and cider.'An Abta spokesperson tells reporter Jane Denton: 'We welcome the Chancellor's announcement, as it is good news for domestic tourism.&nbsp'However, the lack of backing for outbound tourism represents a missed opportunity, as this is a sector that directly provides 220,000 jobs right across the UK and is in urgent need of tailored support. We shall continue to press for additional support measures for the travel and tourism industry in the coming weeks.'Tory chairman of the Education Select Committee Robert Halfon has urged the Chancellor to consider raising the public sector target for apprenticeships.He said: 'I'm over the moon with the Chancellor's statement today. He's rebuilding our apprenticeships and skills nation and ensuring that young people can climb the important ladder of opportunity, so thank you.'The public sector target for apprenticeships is 2.3 per cent.'&lsquoWould he consider raising this target by 5 per cent, which would create 4,000 new apprenticeships in 202021 based on hiring 50,000 new members of staff in the public sector, and will he also change procurement rules to ensure that any big company bidding for a public sector contract must have at least 5 per cent of their workforce employed as apprentices.'Rishi Sunak replied: 'I think he makes two very interesting suggestions and I look forward to discussing them with him further.'More on that VAT cutAccommodation in hotels, B&ampBs, campsites and caravan sites, while attractions such as cinemas, theme parks and zoos will see the tax cut.It will be reduced to 5 per cent from 15 July until 12 January.&nbspThe temporary VAT cut does not include alcoholic drinks.Russell Nathan, senior partner at accountancy firm HW Fisher, said: 'Our restaurants, pubs, shops and hotels are struggling.'This is a timely announcement from Government as businesses are in desperate need of a clear action plan.'It is vital we see the hospitality industry back up and running, and these measures announced today will provide an essential lifeline for many UK businesses.'Sean Glancy, from UHY Hacker Young, says: 'French-style low VAT on food and drink in restaurants and pubs will be a significant help for our leisure industry &ndash it should jump-start the sector and get people back in the doors.'There has been much talk about the risk of a wave of insolvencies among restaurants and bars but leaving gyms out of the VAT cut means that sector should now be on the watch list too.'Tax rises later in the year?Mike Hodges, head of private wealth and partner at accountancy firm Saffery Champness, said: 'Looking ahead, it is difficult to imagine there being any significant revenue raising without increasing some or all of income tax, corporation tax, VAT or NIC at some point.'But fundamentally the key test for the Chancellor will be getting his timings right.'Tax is an important instrument for government, raising revenue by both direct taxation and by encouraging economic growth and transactional activity through targeted use of reliefs &ndash such as stamp duty relief.'The Chancellor will have to balance providing the right reliefs to stimulate economic recovery with raising taxes or cutting back on other reliefs to pay for the very significant investments made in recent months and if the Chancellor is to succeed in, in his words, putting the country&rsquos finances back on a sustainable footing.'What about second homes?With the stamp duty cut announced, landlords and those wanting a second home might wonder what it means for them.Well, according to the documents, stamp duty is cut for them too - but 3 per cent is still required up to &pound500,000.Of the costs of the measures earlier in the year. With today's measures added on, looking at a grand total of &pound190bn so far...Here is how much these measures could cost - up to &pound30billion.&nbspStamp duty cut will potentially cost the Treasury &pound3.8billion. Job Retention Scheme - &pound9.4billion.The Eat Out to Help Out Scheme? &pound500million. The VAT cut for hospitality and some parts of the travel industry is &pound4.1billion.&nbsp&nbspNo help for shops...The British Independent Retailers Association has expressed its disappointment that there is no direct help for retail business owners.Andrew Goodacre, Bira's chief executive, said: 'We welcome the various initiatives to bring younger people into work and the support for the hospitality sector.'However, it is disappointing that there is no VAT cut for retailers in general and no changes to national insurance.'There needs to be thought given to how consumer demand is stimulated on the high street or many businesses will close and jobs lost.'Things that didn't happen...The pensions triple lock is safe for now.There is no car scrappage scheme to help the motor industry.Help for the self-employed who have slipped through the cracks.&nbspTax experts Blick Rothenberg say:&nbsp'It is headline-grabbing stuff. But evidence from previous stamp duty holidays shows that it is unlikely to increase sales volumes and will merely bring them forward.'The end of the holiday was expected to coincide with a significant fall in the market.'That would have made the fall even greater. It is good, therefore, that the holiday is longer than expected at eight months. But even eight months will be too short unless there really is a V shaped recovery.'Those moving in London and the South East will benefit by up to &pound15,000 but are likely to have to pay some tax due to the significantly higher property values in these regions.'It says a typical home sale in the capital is &pound540,000 - the stamp duty will be &pound2,000, as opposed to &pound17,000.&nbspShadow chancellor Anneliese Dodds said Labour acknowledge that the Government has had to make big decisions.Ms Dodds said: 'The Government has had to take big decisions too, we acknowledge that, but today should have been the day when our Government chose to build a bridge between what has been done so far and what needs to be done to get out economy moving again.'Relatively short statement, stamp duty cut, Job Retention Scheme, Kickstart Scheme, green homes vouchers, cheap restaurant eats for August and VAT cut for some are the key policies here.Eat Out, to Help OutHere are measures to help get customers back into restaurants, cafes and pubs.'I can announce today that, for the month of August, we will give everyone in the country an Eat Out to Help Out,' Rishi says.'Meals eaten at any participating business, Monday to Wednesday, will be 50 per cent off, up to a maximum discount of &pound10 per head for everyone, including children. Businesses will need to register, and can do so through a simple website, open next Monday.'Each week in August, businesses can then claim the money back, with the funds in their bank account within five working days.'So, essentially, it is like being in the Tastecard scheme - but without needing to sign up for a free trial. Will it encourage people to eat out next month?VAT cut for some sectorsThe Chancellor wants to see pubs, restaurants, cafes and B&ampBs 'bustling again,' telling MPs: 'At the moment, VAT on hospitality and tourism is charged at 20 per cent'I've decided, for the next six months, to cut VAT on food, accommodation and attractions.'VAT will be reduced from 20 per cent to 5 per cent from 15 July until 12 January to help, noting: 'This is a &pound4billion catalyst for the hospitality and tourism sectors, benefiting over 150,000 businesses, and consumers everywhere - all helping to protect 2.4million jobs.'No surprise, but the stamp duty cut is officially revealed. No stamp duty for homes under &pound500,000. Will run to 31 March 2021 - longer than expected.&nbspThe average bill will fall &pound4,500 and it will help nine in 10 buyers he says. Effective immediately.&nbspRishi Sunak said property transactions fell by 50 per cent in May and house prices have fallen for the first time in eight years.Chris Scott, 37, from Hampshire said all parties in his chain are ready to exchange, but were waiting for this announcement.'We were due to exchange last Friday but was all delayed... until today!' Mr Scott told the PA news agency.'Everyone in the chain woke to the potential news today and everyone is ready to now exchange, then move Friday. But we are waiting until after the announcement at lunchtime.'If the announcement is of an instant freeze we personally will save &pound7,400, and I know further up the chain will save more.'As previously revealed, the Chancellor is creating a green jobs plan to 'save money, cut carbon and create jobs.'&pound2billion will be available for home upgrade to make them greener.&nbspHommeowners and landlords in England will be able to apply for vouchers for the scheme&nbspthis year to pay for green improvements such as loft, wall and floor insulation that could save some households hundreds of pounds a year on their energy bills while creating thousands of jobs for tradespeople, the Treasury says.&nbspA further &pound1billion programme will make public buildings, including schools and hospitals, greener, helping the country meet its ambitions of achieving Net Zero by 2050, whilst investing in our future prosperity, it adds.Suggests it will create 140,000 green jobs.The Chancellor announced a programme to give young people the &lsquobest possible chance&rsquo of getting a job.Government will pay employers to create new jobs for 16-24 year-olds. But they have to be good quality jobs, with a minimum of 25 hours per week at national minimum wage.Government will pay the wages and extra for overheads.Furthermore, the Chancellor says traineeships are a proven scheme to get young people ready for work.'We know they work, so for the first time ever we&rsquoll pay employers &pound1,000 to take on trainees, with triple the number of places.'Stand by your workersIf companies bring back someone who was furloughed - and continuously employ them through to January - the Government will pay a Job Retention Bonus of &pound1,000 per person.'It's vital people aren't just returning for the sake of it - they need to be doing decent work.'So for businesses to get the bonus, the employee must be paid at least &pound520 on average, in each month from November to the end of January - the equivalent of the lower earnings limit in national insurance.'The Chancellor said if employers bring back all nine million people who have been on furlough then it would be a &pound9billion policy.He added: 'Our message to business is clear: if you stand by your workers, we will stand by you.'Rishi Sunak shuts down any potential of the scheme being extended beyond October. Will be criticised no matter what he does, he says.'It will wind down gradually and flexibly until then,' he says.&nbspRishi Sunak says: 'People need to know that we will do all we can to give everyone the opportunity of good and&nbspsecure work.'The most urgent challenge is the looming 'huge job losses.''We face profound economic challenges - the IMF predicts deepest recession since records began,' he adds.He goes on to say that the economy has contracted by 25 per cent in two months - the same amount it grew in the last 18 years.'And the independent OBR and Bank of England are both projecting significant job losses - the most urgent challenge we now face.Here we go...Support for young peopleTory MP Geoffrey Clifton-Brown at PMQs called for support for young people hit hard by the Covid-19 outbreak.He said: 'The coronavirus has hit young people in work and those about to enter the jobs market particularly hard.'Would my right honourable (friend) therefore continue to build on his excellent package of announcements, so far as our young people have hope and&nbspencouragement for the very best prospects at the start of their working life?'Responding Boris Johnson said: 'We want young people to have the self-confidence and the experience of work to keep learning on the job and to get the jobs that they need, and if you wait just a few minutes you'll be hearing rather more from my right honourable friend the Chancellor about that very matter.'Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the furlough scheme 'cannot go on forever.'SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford called for the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme to be extended to support the 'hardest hit sectors' to prevent a spike in unemployment.During PMQs, Mr Johnson replied: 'I think, and I know a lot of people in this House would agree with me, I think that you cannot go on forever with a furlough scheme that keeps people, keeps employees, in suspended animation in the way that it does.'We need to get our economy moving again that's what I think the people of this country want to see in a sustainable and cautious way.'A short video from Rishi Sunak and a reminder of the measures it set out earlier in the year.&nbspWas Saturday so 'super'?Consumers in England put their hands in their pockets over the weekend as spending on pubs and hairdressers came roaring back on Super Saturday - but spending is nowhere near normal levels, reports George Nixon.As George says, eyes will be on what Rishi Sunak has lined up for the hospitality industry as many are still simply put off of non-essential trips and spending.Below, Labour leader Keir Starmer enjoys a pint in London on Monday:&nbspThe Chancellor may announce a temporary or even permanent axing of the state pension triple lock today, but financial experts believe he is more likely to wait until autumn, if he dares to do it at all, writes pensions reporter Tanya Jefferies.There is strong speculation the Government will abandon its manifesto promise to keep the popular guarantee, to help pay the gargantuan bill for fighting the coronavirus crisis, but this would unleash fury among its elderly voters.The 'triple lock' guarantee on annual rises in the state pension means they are decided by whatever is the highest of price inflation, average earnings growth or 2.5 per cent.In April, elderly people got a bumper near-4 per cent rise in the full new state pension to &pound175.20 per week, or to &pound134.25 if they are on the old basic rate. It was set to match the rise in average earnings recorded last July.Removing the triple lock could save the Treasury around &pound4billion a year.Steven Cameron, pensions director at Aegon, says: 'The triple lock was set in a very different pre Covid-19 age when price and earnings growth tended to be relatively stable year on year.'Blindly following that formula now as we move through and out of the coronavirus crisis with huge distortions to average earnings expected could create bizarre results which were never intended and which would fail any test of intergenerational fairness.'If as a result of the furlough scheme we see a sharp dip in average earnings this year followed by a quick and full recovery the next, the triple lock would still grant pensioners a 2.5 per cent minimum increase next year and potentially put them on track for a double digit increase in 2022, while those of working age might have simply regained their pre Covid-19 earnings.'The Chancellor will have to make a call as to whether to suspend the earnings related element or perhaps adjust it to smooth out sharp fluctuations or to make a more fundamental change, with some people viewing it as overly generous.'A quick reminder that Rishi Sunak only became Chancellor on&nbsp13 February 2020.It came after Sajid&nbspJavid reportedly fell out with Boris Johnson's most senior adviser Dominic Cummings, after resisting plans to increase borrowing.He was viewed as a traditional Conservative chancellor, focused more on balancing the books than on delivering some of the bold changes envisioned by Cummings and the Prime Minister.He was the second youngest Chancellor to undertake the Budget speech since George Osborne in 2010 earlier in the year.&nbspHe was born in Southampton and has been MP for Richmond, Yorkshire, since 2014 - the seat previously held by William Hague.He is GP's son who married an Indian tech billionaire's daughter and built a multi million-pound fortune that saw him dubbed the 'Maharaja of the Dales'A graduate of &pound42,000-per-year Winchester College and Oxford University, where he studied PPE, he is believed to be one of the richest members of Parliament, and lives with his family in a magnificent Georgian manor house in the small village of Kirby Sigston, just outside Northallerton in North Yorkshire.A multi-millionaire in his own right thanks to his investment career, Mr Sunak was known to be close to his former boss Sajid Javid, with the pair joining each other on nights out and sharing Star Wars jokes on Twitter.&nbspHis Instagram account depicts a sport-loving family man who dotes on the two daughters he shares with his wife,&nbspAkshata Murthy, whose father N.R. Narayana Murthy is India's sixth-wealthiest man thanks to his ownership of multinational business technology giant&nbspInfosys.&nbspChancellors are never ones to shy away from a good photo opportunity - often grinning manically with that little red box.Earlier in the year, Rishi posted a photograph on his Twitter account with a huge bag of Yorkshire Tea as he made a brew.This time around? He has posed looking over the documents with a &pound180 'smart' cup on his desk. What has he got brewing today...Property expert Henry Pryor has this to say on social media site Twitter...The markets are relatively flat at the moment, but that could all be in anticipation as to what measures are announced today.For example, if the stamp duty holiday is confirmed, it could benefit the housebuilding sector. A VAT cut on tourism could help travel-related stocks.AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould said: 'The FTSE 100 started off sharply lower before yo-yoing back to near parity in early trading.'The market's apparent indecision is understandable when you consider it has to balance the ongoing risks from coronavirus with the willingness of governments and central banks to prop up the global economy.'In the UK there will be focus on Chancellor Rishi Sunak's mini-Budget, with expectations high after lots of trailers in the media suggesting the announcement will contain blockbuster measures to boost the recovery from lockdown.'Another immediate change could be a cut in employer National Insurance for employers to encourage them taking on new staff.Steven Cameron, pensions director at Aegon, says: 'A cut in employer NI would reduce costs for employers and prove a welcome boost to employment.'There are some pension implications to consider because where an employer pays a contribution to an employee&rsquos pension, they don&rsquot pay National Insurance.This has led to some employers offering &lsquosalary sacrifice&rsquo arrangements where employees agree to a pay cut in return for a greater employer pension contribution, with the employer passing on their NI saving to the employee.'If employer NI rates fall, they&rsquoll make less saving on their pension contributions making salary sacrifice arrangements less attractive for them.'Approximately 230,000 of Britain's self-employed continue to be excluded from any Government support because they have had trading profits of &pound50,000 or more in the last three years.&nbspCampaigners are calling on the Chancellor to step in and remove their exclusion from the Self Employment Income Support Scheme, when he makes a summer statement to the House of Commons tomorrow.There are hundreds of thousands of sole traders that have not had any income since March, whereas employees on the furlough scheme can get up to &pound2,500 per month even if they earn more than &pound50,000 a year.From plumbers to dentists, photographers to therapists, we spoke to some of those affected who have paid plenty of income tax in recent years, but now feel penalised while employees in a similar position are helped out.Will there be further measures announced today? Reporter Jayna Rana looks at the mounting pressure the Chancellor faces to help 'forgotten' self-employed whose incomes have all but disappeared.Could you save £15,000 on buying a home?As mentioned below, the stamp duty cut looks likely and it could mean homebuyers may save up to &pound15,000 buying a home.There will be plenty of people awaiting this announcement - especially those in the midst of buying.&nbspProperty reporter Myra Butterworth looks at the towns where homebuyers would benefit the most from a stamp duty cut.It has been suggested that &pound500 should be given to adults and &pound250 to children to spend in shops that have been hit the worst by the Covid-19 pandemic.The proposal, put forward by economic think-tank Resolution Foundation, involves the delivery of up to &pound30billion worth of vouchers for households to spend in stores, as well as on hospitality and leisure.It is commonly described&nbspby economists as 'helicopter money': airlifting cash into the streets.However, it is costly. Giving &pound100 each person would would cost &pound6.7billion, while Steve Donz&eacute, senior strategist at Pictet Asset Management, said all 27.8million UK households should be handed a &pound1,000 cheque from the Bank of England. That would cost &pound27.8billion.Reporter George Nixon took a look over the weekend:&nbspThe ideas to get Britain to spend its way to a V-shaped coronavirus recoveryThe Government is worried about a potential rise in youth unemployment and will reveal its&nbspKickstart scheme, which will run until at least the end of 2021 and open to people aged 16 to 24 who are claiming Universal Credit.&nbspThey will receive the minimum wage, paid by the state, to work 25 hours a week. Their employers&rsquo national insurance and pension contributions will also be paid.And firms will receive an 'administration fee' of around &pound1,000 per employee for arranging the placement.Temporary cuts to VAT could be signalled as part of plans to help retailers and protect jobs.'The government should consider options to stimulate demand, such as a short-term reduction in VAT or a temporary income tax cut for lower-income workers.'It could choose to make cuts for certain sectors, such as tourism.&nbspHowever, HMRC brought in a record &pound135.6bn from VAT receipts in 2018-19. The consumption tax overtook National Insurance to become the second most lucrative UK tax last year.Homeowners could be in line for vouchers of up to &pound5,000 to make energy-saving improvements to their homes as part of a&nbsp&pound2billion 'green deal' scheme.The poorest households will receive vouchers of up to &pound10,000, although renters are understood to be excluded from the grants.&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspUnder the scheme, which will be launched in September, the Government will pay at least two-thirds of the cost of home improvements to save energy.Homeowners will be able to spend the vouchers on things like&nbsphome&nbspinsulation, eco-friendly boilers, double or triple-glazed &shywindows and low energy lighting.&nbspThe Treasury estimates this will save families up to &pound600 a year on energy bills. It will also create jobs - much needed in a employment market hit by the pandemic.&nbspIt looks incredibly likely that there will be a stamp duty cut, with rumours of it coming in for six months on purchases under &pound500,000.Initially, it was reported that the stamp duty cut would not be implemented until autumn.&nbspBut property experts have warned that announcing plans to cut the tax this week and delaying the reduction would put the housing market into deep freeze.&nbspA temporary six-month increase in the stamp duty threshold from the current level of &pound125,000 to an amount between &pound300,000 and &pound500,000 to stimulate demand is reportedly being considered by the Treasury.Welcome to our live coverage of the summer statement, or given another name: the Covid mini-budget.The This is Money team have had their usual morning meeting ahead of the speech, but over video conferencing tool Zoom as we all continue to work from home.It feels like an age since a fresh-faced, new Chancellor - Rishi Sunak - delivered his maiden Budget on 11 March 2020, just days before the coronavirus lockdown was announced.Just four months on, and there are a number of measures that the Chancellor is looking at to help the post-coronavirus economy...
